DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said the US will hold discussions with China over currency issues in the next round of talks with PBoC's Yi Gang, while he also commented that the US will begin a trade deal with China if it is a good deal. (Newswires/Fox)

Sources close to the White House pointed to the APEC Summit in Chile on November 13th-14th as a possible venue for a follow-up Trump-Xi bilateral meeting, although it was also suggested US and Chinese officials would have to complete two productive rounds of talks before then. (CNBC)

US filed criminal charges against a Chinese professor in Texas who is linked to Huawei. (WSJ)

US Secretary of State Pompeo said he is looking forward to completing a deal with Japan at the UN General Assembly and stated they have reached a consensus on agricultural, digital and industrial issues. (Twitter) 

 

UK/EU

UK Parliament will be prorogued tonight according to a PM Spokesman who added that we will not seek a Brexit extension and will leave on October 31st. There were also comments from UK Foreign Secretary Raab that the government will respect the rule of law but also stated PM Johnson won't go to Brussels to ask for an extension and instead will go there to negotiate a deal. (Newswires)

UK parliament voted (311-302) in favour of forcing the government to show all documents regarding its no-deal planning as well as private messages related to the decision to suspend parliament as expected. (Newswires)

UK House of Commons speaker Bercow said if Parliament does not vote for a general election today, he will be standing down on October 31st but if an election was called, he will step down on the date of the election. (Newswires)

UK opposition Labour Party is reportedly considering tabling a confidence vote on PM Johnson on October 22nd after instructing its MPs to vote down the Queen's Speech a day beforehand. In other news, earlier reports suggested that November 28th was doing the rounds as a potential date for a UK election. (Telegraph/Twitter)

UK & Irish PM's joint statement stated they agreed discussions are at an early stage and although common ground was established in some areas, significant gaps remain. In related news, EU politicians reportedly welcome tone UK PM Johnson used in meeting today although want to see rhetoric followed-up with action, while it was also suggested that the Northern Ireland only backstop seems the only way to appease both sides and that the EU is more than aware that PM Johnson still needs the numbers in Parliament. (ITV/BBC/Twitter)

A senior EU official stated that at the end of the day, an Article 50 extension would be granted in the case that there is a clear intention to hold a general election according to Buzzfeed's Nardelli. In related news, other EU members were said to be dismissive today of the declared French position that they could say no to a UK request for another Brexit extension, according to BBC's Adler. (Twitter)

UK Government has reportedly seen polling which indicated PM Johnson would do worse than former PM May if there was to be an election now, according to Sky's Coates citing SPAD Stein. (Twitter)

Germany are reportedly considering the creation of a 'shadow budget' to increase public investments beyond restrictions of national debt rules, according to sources. The reports added that officials are considering the idea of setting up independent public entities to take the opportunity of zero borrowing costs, while the debt financing of these bodies would not be accounted for under the German fiscal rules and instead be under the more lenient European Union Stability and Growth Pact. (Newswires)

Italian PM Conte said citizens income measure has been confirmed and that the government does not intend to dismantle welfare measures for those with low income. PM Conte also commented the new government will seek to raise funds by cutting spending, revamping tax expenditures and stepping up its fight against tax evasion. Furthermore, Conte reiterated calls for changes to the EU's stability and growth pact, while he added that the new government will start a path of debt reduction. (Newswires)

  • UK GDP Estimate (Jul) M/M 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. 0.0%). (Newswires)
  • UK GDP Estimate (Jul) Y/Y 1.0% vs. Exp. 0.8% (Prev. 1.0%)
  • UK GDP Est 3M/3M (Jul) 0.0% vs. Exp. -0.1% (Prev. -0.2%)
  • UK Industrial Output (Jul) M/M 0.1% vs. Exp. -0.1% (Prev. -0.1%)
  • UK Industrial Output (Jul) Y/Y -0.9% vs. Exp. -1.1% (Prev. -0.6%)

 

COMMODITIES

Saudi Energy Minister Abdulaziz said he hopes oil production in the second half is better than the first half in terms of production and is aiming for the Aramco IPO as soon as possible. (Newswires)

Oman Energy Minister said he is satisfied with oil at USD 60/bbl but wants oil at USD 70/bbl and said there is concern about the compliance of one or two members of the OPEC+ group. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump said he could meet with Iran's Rouhani and has no problem with the idea, while he stated 'we'll see what happens' regarding a meeting with North Korea in September. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said they are looking at sanctions regarding Turkey's purchase of the Russian S-400 missile system, although no decision has been taken yet. (Newswires)

North Korean Vice-Foreign Minister said his country it is willing to meet with the US this month to discuss issues. (Newswires)

 

US

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said he does not see a US recession and does not see the yield curve signalling a recession but instead sees a positive year ahead, while he also stated the US will consider more tax cuts next year. (Newswires/Fox)

 

MARKET RECAP

Apple Inc. (AAPL) and Foxconn (2354 TT) reportedly violated a Chinese labour rule by having around a 50% temporary workforce in a Chinese plant, which is in contravention of Chinese Labour law which sets a maximum limit of 10%. AT&T Inc. (T) traded higher after it received a letter from Elliot Management recommending the company to divest its non-core assets in a value creation method which will give the name a USD 60/shr value by 2021. AT&T (T) however later reportedly hired Goldman Sachs to defend against the activist. Further, AT&T CEO Randall Stephenson, came under fire from the activists over some ‘questionable M&A decisions’ as they call for a leadership reshuffle. Elsewhere, Netflix (NFLX) was boosted after Bank of America said it sees significant reacceleration in Q3, with downloads tracking 30% higher. Eli Lilly (LLY) presented data from its LOXO-292 clinical trial which saw tumours shrink in 68% of advanced lung cancer patients whose tumours carried specific abnormalities in the RET gene. Alibaba’s (BABA) CEO, Jack Ma, announced he is to step down on Tuesday. Nissan (NSANY) CEO also announced his resignation after he recently admitted to being overpaid, his resignation is to become effective on September 16th. In broker moves, Energiser (ENR) & Nutanix (NTNX) were double upgraded at Bank of America and Susquehanna, and Fox (FOXA) were downgraded to underperform from neutral at Macquarie, and HP Inc. (HPQ) downgraded to market perform from outperform at Bernstein. S&P 500 0% at 2978, NASDAQ-100 -0.3% at 7832, Dow Jones 0.2% at 26836.

The Treasury curve bear-steepened, taking its cues from the Bund in afternoon trade. Some desks had cited a more constructive risk tone in early trade for the rise in yields, with fewer concerns on the US/China trade front, while the notion of central bank easing was also being attributed (which is difficult to buy, given one usually expects yields to fall on the latter). The US Treasury will this week auction a new 3-year note (USD 38bln, Tuesday), a 10-year re-opening (USD 24bln, Wednesday), and a 30-year bond (USD 16bln, Thursday); UBS notes that that there will be around USD 26bln of cashflows (ex-SOMA) this week, including USD 24bln of redemptions and USD 2bln of coupons. Analysts at BMO say that this week's supply could offer a further concessionary impulse as September's 3s/10s/30s auctions are the final primary market coupon opportunity before the Fed once again (very likely) lowers policy. US T-note (U9) settled 16+ ticks lower at 130-27+.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 9th September 2019: Markets mixed ahead of this week’s ECB and key US data
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities mixed, Treasuries down, Crude up, Dollar down.
  • REAR VIEW: Germany continues to mull fiscal stimulus; UK GDP surprises on the upside; Mnuchin will talk FX with China; New Saudi energy minister supports crude.
  • COMING UP: Chinese & Norwegian Inflation, Norges Bank Regional Survey, UK Labour Market Report, US NFIB Small Business Optimism, Canadian Housing Starts, Building Permits, US JOLTS; US 3yr auction.

 

* MARKETS WRAP: The risk-on tone seen in the US pre-market proved to be fleeting, and indices have begun the week in negative territory. An afternoon sell-off was not attributed to any specific news, but desks had noted that the moves lower were led by momentum names coming under pressure. Some also suggested there was a rotation from large cap to smaller caps, as the RUT remained resilient; some newswires attributed the softness to questions whether likely upcoming stimulus measures from global central banks would be successful in staving off a growth slowdown. Gold came under pressure on Monday, as negative real rates pared, and the US 10-year yield found its way above 1.6%, seeing the yellow metal find lows sub USD 1500. Meanwhile, the US Treasury curve bear-steepened, taking cues from the Bund, where downside was exacerbated after a report suggesting the Germans were looking at other ways to issue debt for infrastructure and green projects; the EUR also gained on the news. The dollar is lower on the day. Oil was firmer after a new energy minister was appointed in Saudi Arabia, who remains committed to the OPEC supply curb pact. The market's attention is focussed on Thursday's ECB meeting, as well as US CPI and retail sales towards the end of the week.

* MNUCHIN: In a broad interview, Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said he did not see a US recession. He said that the US will consider further tax cuts next year. On China, Mnuchin said that he would discuss the yuan level with PBOC governor Yi Gang in the next round of talks. And on geopolitics, Mnuchin said that the US is still mulling sanctions on Turkey after its purchase of Russian S-400 missile system.

* GERMANY FISCAL STIMULUS: Germany is considering the creation of a shadow budget that would enable Berlin to boost public investment beyond the restrictions of constitutionally enshrined debt rules, Reuters reported citing three sources familiar with discussions. The measure would involve setting up independent public entities that would capitalise on historically low yields to raise debt to invest in infrastructure and climate protection. The debt would not be accounted for under Germany's strict fiscal rules, instead, it would be under the more lenient rules of the EU's stability and growth pact. Some German lawmakers have been examining measures to boost fiscal spending amid the growth slowdown. In reaction to the news, Bunds saw downside, while the EUR rose. Elsewhere, Germany could reportedly face a shortfall in tax revenue in 2020/21, according to Handelsblatt.

* BREXIT: Foreign Minister Raab on the weekend said that the UK government would abide by Parliamentary legislation blocking a no deal Brexit, but would look to test it legally, perhaps in court, and raised the possibility of a non-governmental body bringing a court case to test the legislation. PM Johnson himself on Monday said he would abide by the Brexit law if forced to do so by courts. The Telegraph newspaper has reported that the government has plans to circumvent the Brexit legislation, by requesting an extension (per the legislation) but sending an accompanying letter expressing that the government does not support a delay. Over the weekend, the French Foreign Minister questioned the logic of another Brexit extension, adding that the EU did not want to give extensions every three months. This sentiment, however, is not universal, BBC's Katya Adler reported, stating that the common EU assumption is that the bloc would say yes to a UK extension request. An election now seems inevitable (MPs will likely vote again this evening, and although the expectation is that the government will lose again, it seems only a matter of time now before Brits go to the polls); accordingly, sensitivities around the timing of the election are easing, leaving the focus on how Parliament will look, post election. Polls continue to indicate the Tories hold a lead over Labour, however, when you merge parties into 'leave' and 'remain' groups, the situation is more balanced. Elsewhere, House Speaker Bercow said he will stand down as both a speaker and an MP at the next election, or on 31st October, whichever came first.

* UK JULY GDP: GDP rose by 0.3% M/M in July, ahead of the consensus 0.1%, helping the 3m/3m measure to go flat from -0.2% in June. Services did the heavy lifting, where there was broad-based strength. The +0.3% in manufacturing may be a result of Brexit stockpiling, analysts said, though it only contributed to 0.03ppts of GDP growth. Pantheon's analysts said the data could signal growth of 0.4% in Q3; "With little spare capacity left in the economy, a fiscal boost coming  and CPI inflation set to exceed the 2% target from the second half of 2020 onwards, we continue to think that markets are wrong to price-in a greater-than 50% chance of the MPC cutting Bank Rate over the next six months."

* BOE: BoE's Vlieghe said structural forces, which were unrelated to monetary policy, are unlikely to keep interest rates low. Vlieghe said BoE analysis rules out taking rates negative, and that the BOE was unlikely to be able to cut rates as it did in the previous downturn. He argued that more QE was unlikely to provide much stimulus, since there is not much room for UK Gilt yields to fall further.

* WTI (V9) SETTLES USD 1.33 HIGHER AT USD 57.85/BBL; BRENT (X9) SETTLES USD 1.05 HIGHER AT USD 62.59/BBL. Saudi Arabia has vowed that it would continue to support OPEC+ oil output cuts under new energy minister Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman. Oil markets welcomed the new minister, despite his predecessor being respected in the market, and playing an instrumental role in engineering the supply cut deal. Analysts said it may be a reflection that the market is seeing the move as a sign of concern in Saudi Arabia that oil prices are holding at levels below Saudi's fiscal breakeven price. UBS said Saudi energy policy is already aimed at pushing oil prices higher, with production and export cuts that go well beyond commitments as part of the OPEC+ agreement, but the bank says that "we may see a shift in both messaging about Saudi’s goals and about the relatively relaxed stance Saudi has taken towards compliance by other OPEC+ participants. This week’s OPEC Joint Ministerial Monitoring Committee is not a forum that would usually be much cause for excitement, but may turn out to be an early opportunity to gauge whether Saudi policy or messaging will be affected by the appointment of the new Energy Minister." Elsewhere, the US DOE awarded contracts for nearly 9.88mln barrels of SPR crude to four US companies, with deliveries to take place in October and November; no dollar amounts were stated.

* PBOC MIXED SIGNALS: Last week's RRR cut, accompanied by a targeted rate cut, was considered aggressive - it was the first time since 2015 that the central bank announced both on the same day. Analysts said it sent an easing signal, especially since the long-term liquidity injected would not be used to replace maturing MLF. However, on Monday, the PBOC skipped MLF rollover this morning, effectively replacing the 1-year MLF with shorter-term 7-day reverse repos, which is more of a hawkish signal than was sent out last week. UBS says that, by doing this, the PBOC is taking back control of interbank market liquidity in the medium-term and is ensuring that it can withdraw liquidity whenever it deems appropriate. UBS reasons that it is possible that an immediate MLF cut after RRR cut would be too strong a signal when China wants to control the pace of Yuan depreciation, and the bank suggests keeping an eye on the MLFs that mature next week.

* FX WRAP: A softer dollar -- partly inspired by a stronger EUR on hopes of German stimulus -- did not result in a haven bid, with the JPY, CHF and even XAU off (the latter quite notably, as US yields rise). The offshore yuan traded higher despite DXY downside, which some had suggested was putting pressure on EMFX, with the exception of ZAR, which newswires had suggested was a result of 'Fed rate cut bets spurring buying'. Sterling has firmed as no deal Brexit risks are slowly taken off the table, but traders are still cognizant of measures the Johnson government might attempt to drive through a no deal. CAD continued on last week's upside, helped along by higher oil prices. The RUB was also higher on oil. The antipodes were higher, again with hopes of stimulus being cited.

* US T-NOTE (U9) SETTLE 16+ TICKS LOWER AT 130-27+. The Treasury curve bear-steepened, taking its cues from the Bund in afternoon trade. Some desks had cited a more constructive risk tone in early trade for the rise in yields, with fewer concerns on the US/China trade front, while the notion of central bank easing was also being attributed (which is difficult to buy, given one usually expects yields to fall on the latter). The US Treasury will this week auction a new 3-year note (USD 38bln, Tuesday), a 10-year re-opening (USD 24bln, Wednesday), and a 30-year bond (USD 16bln, Thursday); UBS notes that that there will be around USD 26bln of cashflows (ex-SOMA) this week, including USD 24bln of redemptions and USD 2bln of coupons. Analysts at BMO say that this week's supply could offer a further concessionary impulse as September's 3s/10s/30s auctions are the final primary market coupon opportunity before the Fed once again (very likely) lowers policy rates.

* CLOSING LEVELS: S&P 500 0% at 2978, NASDAQ-100 -0.3% at 7832, Dow Jones 0.2% at 26836

* SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary 0.3%, Consumer Staples -0.3%, Energy 1.9%, Financials 1.5%, Health Care -0.9%, Industrials 0.3%, Information Technology -0.7%, Materials -0.5%, Telecommunication Services 0.2%, Utilities -0.6%

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Apple Inc. (AAPL) and Foxconn (2354 TT) reportedly violated a Chinese labour rule by having around a 50% temporary workforce in a Chinese plant, which is in contravention of Chinese Labour law which sets a maximum limit of 10%. AT&T Inc. (T) traded higher after it received a letter from Elliot Management recommending the company to divest its non-core assets in a value creation method which will give the name a USD 60/shr value by 2021. AT&T (T) however later reportedly hired Goldman Sachs to defend against the activist. Further, AT&T CEO Randall Stephenson, came under fire from the activists over some ‘questionable M&A decisions’ as they call for a leadership reshuffle. Elsewhere, Netflix (NFLX) was boosted after Bank of America said it sees significant reacceleration in Q3, with downloads tracking 30% higher. Eli Lilly (LLY) presented data from its LOXO-292 clinical trial which saw tumours shrink in 68% of advanced lung cancer patients whose tumours carried specific abnormalities in the RET gene. Alibaba’s (BABA) CEO, Jack Ma, announced he is to step down on Tuesday. Nissan (NSANY) CEO also announced his resignation after he recently admitted to being overpaid, his resignation is to become effective on September 16th. In broker moves, Energiser (ENR) & Nutanix (NTNX) were double upgraded at Bank of America and Susquehanna, and Fox (FOXA) were downgraded to underperform from neutral at Macquarie, and HP Inc. (HPQ) downgraded to market perform from outperform at Bernstein.

content:
GBP/EUR

The Pound is off best levels, but still well ahead of the chasing G10 pack after a run of considerably better than expected UK data, including July GDP, industrial production, output and trade, plus positive sounding comments from PM Johnson at the start of his meeting with Irish counterpart Varadkar. Meanwhile, the former’s 2nd attempt to force an election is widely expected to fall short again and the Queen has now given her seal of approval to the anti-no deal Brexit/extension bill, reducing the prospect of a cliff edge scenario. Cable extended gains to just shy of the 1.2385 July 29 high and stops said to be sitting on a break and Eur/Gbp got to within a handful of pips from 0.8900 and not much further from a key Fib retracement level/support just under the big figure at 0.8892. However, as Sterling stalled/waned with House speaker Bercow announcing that he would stand down on October 31 if Parliament does not back an election, the single currency got a boost from a firmer rebound in Bund/Eurozone bond yields following reports that Germany could use a ‘shadow budget’ to get round stringent and self-imposed debt rules to boost public spending. Indeed, Eur/Usd broke out of its earlier constricted range, but eased back below 1 bn 1.1050 option expiries ahead of the NY cut before probing higher again shortly afterwards. So far, the headline pair has reached 1.1064, very close to resistance at 1.1065 and then a Fib at 1.1088, while the cross is back up near 0.8950.

AUD/NZD/NOK/CAD 

The Aussie is still revelling in more neutral/balanced RBA guidance, constructive US-China trade developments and the PBoC latest RRR reductions, with Aud/Usd up to 0.6875 and further outpacing the Kiwi that lost altitude vs its US peer on the way to 0.6450 and faded against its Antipodean rival above 1.0650. Elsewhere, the Norwegian Krona got a double boost from strong GDP data and a strengthening rebound in crude prices, as Eur/Nok continued its retreat from recent peaks (around 10.0000) to almost 9.8500 at one stage, and the Loonie also derived traction from oil to eclipse technical support at 1.3156 and 1.3150 before waning.

JPY/CHF/XAU 

Although risk assets were not uniformly bid or in demand, the traditional safe-havens underperformed with the Yen gradually weakening through 107.00, Franc back below 0.9900 and Gold slipping back under Usd1500/oz as the DXY held above 98.000 and Fib support (98.034), albeit towards the middle of a 98.167-512 range.

EM

The aforementioned bounce in crude undermined the Try alongside ongoing expectations and external pressure on the CBRT to slash rates this week, but the Lira was also jittery after remarks from US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin about S-400 sanctions that are still under consideration. Usd/Try rallied beyond 5.7600 before paring back a bit, while in contrast Usd/Rub and Usd/Zar both maintained their downward trajectories to circa 65.3600 and 14.6700 respectively.

subject: Fixed and FX latest: bonds remain weak and Sterling strong
content: European benchmarks have extended losses in early pm trade, and this time Bunds have taken the lead amidst yet more reports about German fiscal stimulus with the latest talk surrounding a ‘shadow budget’ to sidestep Berlin’s strict debt rules. The 10 year German benchmark hit a fresh Eurex low of 174.45 (-78 ticks), and Gilts fell in sympathy to 122.17 (-93 ticks), while US Treasuries slipped back towards worst levels. Similarly, while the Pound remains top in the major stakes, Eur/Usd climbed to almost 1.1060 before losing impetus and perhaps gravitating back to nearly 2 bn expiries at 1.1050, while the DXY remains near the base of its 98.178-512 range.

  • European indices are little changed and lacking direction thus far this morning [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.1%] ahead of a quiet slate for the day
  • Sterling is strong ahead of today’s hectic UK Parliament schedule, which may well be the last until October 14th
  • Apple (AAPL) and Foxconn have reportedly violated a Chinese labour rule through the use of around 50% temporary workforce in a Chinese plant during August
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Norges Bank’s Matsen and UK Parliament

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mostly positively but with gains relatively mild as the region digested the latest developments from the world’s 2 largest economies including the PBoC RRR cut announcement, mostly weaker than expected Chinese trade data and US NFP. ASX 200 (U/C) was choppy as upside in tech was counterbalanced by continued weakness in gold miners and after soft Chinese trade data which showed a surprise drop in Exports, while Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) remained afloat after Final GDP figures for Q2 printed inline with estimates. Hang Seng (Unch.) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.8%) were mixed as the mainland reacted to the PBoC’s 50bps RRR cut and further targeted 100bps reduction for qualified banks which is expected to release CNY 900bln of liquidity, although advances were limited by the weak trade figures and with Hong Kong dampened after further violent protests over the weekend. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher despite the mostly positive risk tone and reclaimed the 155.00 level, although prices later stalled amid mixed results in the enhanced liquidity auction for 2yr-20yr JGBs.

PBoC injected CNY 120bln via 7-day reverse repos but skipped MLF operations vs. CNY 176.5bln of MLFs maturing. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0851 vs. Exp. 7.0940 (Prev. 7.0855)

Heavy protests continued over the weekend in Hong Kong where police used tear gas to keep protesters from blocking the airport. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

China to invest USD 280bln into Iran with USD 120bln towards oil and industrial infrastructure. (Newswires)

UK/EU – Summary outlining the schedule for Brexit today & points to note

UK Parliament is to be prorogued tonight and thereafter will not return until October 14th., Mirror's Bloom. (Twitter) Subsequently confirmed by a PM spokesperson. (Newswires)

Irish PM Varadkar says if there is a request for a Brexit extension from the UK, most countries would not want one, but if there is a good reason then we would consider this. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson was reported to draw up a plan to legally sabotage Brexit extension if MPs vote against holding a general election, as such the government believes that today’s vote is the “last chance” for MPs to prevent a no-deal exit. (Telegraph) However, there were later reports that PM Johnson signalled to cabinet ministers the government would have to accept a 3-month Brexit delay if it is forced on him by the courts. (Times)

UK opposition lawmakers are to request emergency debate on Monday to try force government to publish a no-deal planning document and emergency debate regarding PM Johnson adhering to law on Brexit delay. (Newswires)

UK Work and Pensions Minister Amber Rudd quit the Cabinet and the Conservative Party on Saturday night in which she criticized the “short-sighted” ousting of pro-EU MPs and stated that she believed PM Johnson was aiming for a no-deal Brexit. (Newswires)

French Foreign Minister said that Brussels will not grant the UK an extension to A50 if the current circumstances remain the same. (Politico)

Plaid Cymru reportedly wish to use cross party discussions to consider the idea of impeaching UK PM Johnson in the event that he attempts to stop a Brexit extension. (Sky News)

ECB’s De Guindos said policy can play a greater countercyclical and stabilizing role, while he added that fiscal space should be used wisely in countries where it exists. (Newswires)

ECB are reportedly examining whether and how the ECB could purchase shares on stock exchanges in the event of an emergency (the article does not specify what would qualify as an emergency)., SuedDeutsche

EQUITIES

Major European indices are mixed this morning but overall little changed [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.1%], as markets struggle for clear direction amidst a relatively quiet schedule and no further updates to the US-China trade situation. Unsurprisingly, sectors are painting a similar picture this morning though the energy sector outperforms amidst strength in the broader complex. In terms of individual movers, ProSiebensat (+5.5%) lead the Stoxx 600 after being upgraded to buy at UBS and the Co. stating they are to remain focused on their free-to-air business. At the other end of the spectrum are ThyssenKrupp (-2.3%) after the Co’s CEO states he would prefer a minority stake sale in their elevator division which has the potential to be valued at over EUR 15bln. Meanwhile, opening remarks from his meeting with Irish PM Varadkar were largely upbeat and confident on the subject of resolving the Irish border backstop, including alternatives to the current WA proposal as he claimed there are many prospective options, but not for public consumption. In response and/or follow-through from the aforementioned encouraging data, Cable cleared 1.2300 more convincingly on its way over the 55 DMA (1.2328) and above last Friday’s post-NFP high (1.2338) to circa 1.2360, while Eur/Gbp reversed through the big figure and 0.8950, eyeing 0.8900 next.

AUD/NZD/NOK/CAD - The Antipodean Dollars have extended recovery gains vs their US counterpart in wake of the latest PBoC RRR cuts, a sub-forecast rise in US payrolls and despite Chinese trade data revealing an unexpected decline in exports. Ahead, the next instalments from Westminster and a pretty barren US slate with only consumer credit scheduled.

COMMODITIES

Brent and WTI prices are firmer this morning, with both WTI and Brent having successfully surpassed the USD 57.00/bbl and USD 62.00/bbl marks at best thus far. Nothing too fresh in the way of fundamental news flow this morning, but weekend reports showed that Saudi Energy Minister Al Falih has been replaced by Prince Abdulaziz; PVM indicate that no changed is to be expected in the current strategy of OPEC and if anything this may strengthen their resolve to balance markets. Other energy minister comments from Secretary General Barkindo that the JMMC could debate potential new production targets, meeting is scheduled for September 12th. The complex may have derived some support this morning from renewed geopolitical tensions via Iran, who have told the IAEA that they intend to produce enriched uranium with advanced centrifuges and as such would breach the nuclear deals imposed ban. Although, gold has failed to generate too much in the way of support from these comments with the yellow metal little changed on the day and still holding above the USD 1500/oz mark going into a critical week for markets courtesy of the ECB on Thursday. Separately, China’s Iron imports increased 6% YY to their highest since January 2018, which ING note is due to increasing shipments from Australia and amidst a recovery in Brazilian exports.

subject: ING see EUR/USD lower for longer as dollar strength continues
content:
ING have revised lower their forecast for EUR/USD; they see the cross moving into a 1.05-1.10 for the remainder of year. The bank cites four main reasons behind the revision in its forecast:

1) Further deterioration in the US-China trade war – ING, amongst a number of other desks, foresee a further deterioration in trade tensions between the US and China, despite recent positive rhetoric, as China stands firm in its rejection of some of the US’ key demands. There is also the risk that the US may impose sanctions on EU exports, the bank reminds us, as made clear over the weekend by reports that despite the agreement at the G7, the US is still mulling taxing imports of French Wine. ING expect such risks to dissuade investor from entering strategic long positions.

2) The bar is high for a “dovish” Fed surprise – There is already very aggressive market expectations of Fed easing, making it hard for the Fed to 'surprise', ING argues. The bank argues that for dovish expectations to be exceeded, the Fed would have to embark on an aggressive easing cycle, which they argue is unlikely given the strength of the consumer (as evidenced by recent retail sales prints). Although a further slowdown in global growth could also spur more aggressive Fed rate cuts, it would likely be accompanied by further easing by other global central banks (as we are seeing at the moment), maintaining the dollars favourable carry.

3) EUR/USD no longer has a stretched valuation – Based on the bank’s model, EUR/USD BEER fair value declined due to an improvement in the US terms of trade (one of the key explanatory variables in the model). “With EUR/USD no longer stretched, this means that the pair has scope to decline even further before hitting the valuation limits” says ING.

4) Speculative EUR shorts are not excessive – ING note that speculative positioning is currently not stretched, at 8% of open interest versus an average 30% between mid-2014 and end-2016. “This means that more EUR shorts can still be built and positioning does not act as a limiting factor behind the EUR/USD fall” the banks says.

A side note on this week’s ECB meeting:

While a disappointment from the ECB meeting this week could push EUR/USD higher, ING would expect such EUR strength to be temporary, as a lack of stimulus would likely increase market concern about the eurozone's economic outlook and lead to a further deterioration in growth and inflation expectations. This, the bank argues, could lead to an even bigger need for subsequent easing and, as such, a potential EUR/USD rebound this week should be seen as an attractive entry point for preparing for lower EUR/USD levels later this year.

subject: ANALYSIS: UK Parliament prorogation, Benn bill and timings
content:
Today’s Timings – as always with politics timings are approximate

  • UK PM Johnson in Ireland with Irish PM Varadkar today to presumably discuss the Irish Backstop and likely their opinion on a further extension to Article 50
  • Benn bill is to receive Royal assent
  • Emergency (SO24) debate to force the publication of no-deal planning and documentation
  • 16:30BST – Parliament will begin debating the motions against proroguing parliament
  • 22:00BST – The formal bid for prorogation will be placed

Looking Ahead

  • September 11th – PM Johnson is to appear before the House of Commons Liaison Committee, responding to questions on, amongst other topics, Brexit
  • September 11th – Scotland’s highest civil court is expected to rule on whether the prorogation of parliament is legal
  • September 19th: BoE Rate Decision
  • September 22nd- 25th: Labour Party Conference
  • September 28th – October 2nd: Tory Party Conference
  • October 14th: Queen’s Speech
  • October 17th: Potential General Election date 
  • October 17th- 18th: European Council Meeting (Informal deadline for a Brexit deal to be agreed)
  • October 21st – 22nd: Votes on the Queen’s Speech
  • October 31st: Scheduled Brexit date
  • November 7th: BoE Rate Decision and QIR

What to watch for

  • Irish PM Varadkar has stated he does not expect much to result from the UK in terms of today’s negotiations, although most recently believes that some common ground can be found but is yet to see any alternative proposals to the Irish Backstop. As such, focus on these comments will be if any new proposals are offered and if this ‘common ground’ equates to a fundamental change in the narrative
  • In terms of the prorogation, consensus is now that this cannot be stopped legally though September 11th should see a ruling from the Scottish civil court on whether this is legal. Although, if today goes to the governments plan it is unclear as to how much of an effect such a ruling would have.
  • Regarding the Benn bill which, in essence, would compel Johnson to seek a further extension from the EU, and then accept one if this is offered. The bill is due to receive Royal assent today at which point it will formally be written into UK law. In-spite of this, PM Johnson continues to reiterate his stance that we must leave by October 31st and is reportedly to draw up plans to legally sabotage a Brexit extension; although, further reports indicate that Johnson would have to accept such a delay if it is forced on him by the legal system.
  • Finally, today’s SO24 emergency bills are designed to force the Government to publish no-deal planning documentation alongside an emergency debate on PM Johnson adhering to the law. This specifically refers to the prorogation advice the government have taken and any further details to the Yellowhammer documents. And the debate on the PM adhering to the law is likely aimed at defining the legal ramifications and what Parliament can do in the event that Johnson chooses to defy the Benn bill and as such break the law. (ITV's Paul Brand)

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

9th September 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mostly positively but with gains relatively mild as the region digested the latest developments from the world’s 2 largest economies including the PBoC RRR cut announcement, mostly weaker than expected Chinese trade data and US NFP. ASX 200 (+0.1%) was choppy as upside in tech was counterbalanced by continued weakness in gold miners and after soft Chinese trade data which showed a surprise drop in Exports, while Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) remained afloat after Final GDP figures for Q2 printed inline with estimates. Hang Seng (Unch.) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) were mixed as the mainland reacted to the PBoC’s 50bps RRR cut and further targeted 100bps reduction for qualified banks which is expected to release CNY 900bln of liquidity, although advances were limited by the weak trade figures and with Hong Kong dampened after further violent protests over the weekend.

FTSE 100

Morrisons (MRW LN) – Industry chatter indicates that the Co. has become a cheap takeover target, as the Co. has a attractive store portfolio and a relationship with Amazon (AMZN LN); although, some are sceptical that this is correct and Sainsbury’s (SBRY LN) may be a better target. (Telegraph)

Sainsbury’s (SBRY LN) – Co. is reportedly preparing a major overhaul of its bank, as part of their back to basic strategy following the failed ASDA [Walmart (WMT)] merger. Sources indicate the Co. may be planning to offload its mortgage book, as one of the options for its financial services component. (Telegraph)

RBS (RBS LN) – Co, is said to have received 200k PPI claims on final day with average payout at GBP 2000 which could result to costs of GBP 400mln. (Newswires)

IAG (IAG LN) – British Airways pilots are due to strike today and tomorrow over pay disputes, with warnings that up to 100% of flights could be cancelled and the majority have already been cancelled; and further disruptions to services may be present on Wednesday. As such, British Airways passengers have been advised to avoid airports during the strike action. (Sky/BBC)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 9th September 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets traded mostly positively with gains capped by soft trade metrics from China and ongoing unrest in Hong Kong
  • UK PM Johnson has reportedly drawn up a plan to legally sabotage a Brexit extension if MPs vote against holding a general election
  • Saudi Arabia removed Energy Minister Al-Falih from his position and replaced him with Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman bin Abdulaziz al-Saud
  • Fed Chair Powell provided a relatively upbeat view of the economy which suggested a lack of urgency for a more aggressive move by the Fed
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German Trade Balance; UK GDP (Estimate) & Services, BoE’s Vlieghe

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mostly positively but with gains relatively mild as the region digested the latest developments from the world’s 2 largest economies including the PBoC RRR cut announcement, mostly weaker than expected Chinese trade data and US NFP. ASX 200 (+0.1%) was choppy as upside in tech was counterbalanced by continued weakness in gold miners and after soft Chinese trade data which showed a surprise drop in Exports, while Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) remained afloat after Final GDP figures for Q2 printed inline with estimates. Hang Seng (Unch.) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) were mixed as the mainland reacted to the PBoC’s 50bps RRR cut and further targeted 100bps reduction for qualified banks which is expected to release CNY 900bln of liquidity, although advances were limited by the weak trade figures and with Hong Kong dampened after further violent protests over the weekend. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher despite the mostly positive risk tone and reclaimed the 155.00 level, although prices later stalled amid mixed results in the enhanced liquidity auction for 2yr-20yr JGBs.

PBoC injected CNY 120bln via 7-day reverse repos but skipped MLF operations vs. CNY 176.5bln of MLFs maturing. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0851 vs. Exp. 7.0940 (Prev. 7.0855)

Heavy protests continued over the weekend in Hong Kong where police used tear gas to keep protesters from blocking the airport. (Newswires)

Chinese Trade Balance (USD)(Aug) 34.84B vs. Exp. 43.0B (Prev. 45.06B, Rev. 44.61B). (Newswires) Chinese Exports (USD)(Aug) Y/Y -1.0% vs. Exp. 2.0% (Prev. 3.3%) Chinese Imports (USD)(Aug) Y/Y -5.6% vs. Exp. -6.0% (Prev. -5.6%, Rev. -5.3%) Chinese FX Reserves (Aug) 3.107tln vs. Exp. 3.100tln (Prev. 3.104tln)

Japanese GDP (Q2 F) Q/Q 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.4%). (Newswires) Japanese GDP (Q2 F) Y/Y 1.3% vs. Exp. 1.3% (Prev. 1.8%)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson was reported to draw up a plan to legally sabotage Brexit extension if MPs vote against holding a general election, as such the government believes that today’s vote is the “last chance” for MPs to prevent a no-deal exit. (Telegraph) However, there were later reports that PM Johnson signalled to cabinet ministers the government would have to accept a 3-month Brexit delay if it is forced on him by the courts. (Times)

Two polls published over the weekend (Opinium, YouGov) give the Conservatives a commanding lead over Labour, suggesting that PM Johnson’s hardline stance on Brexit is resonating with voters. (Telegraph)

UK opposition lawmakers are to request emergency debate on Monday to try force government to publish a no-deal planning document and emergency debate regarding PM Johnson adhering to law on Brexit delay. (Newswires)

UK Work and Pensions Minister Amber Rudd quit the Cabinet and the Conservative Party on Saturday night in which she criticized the “short-sighted” ousting of pro-EU MPs and stated that she believed PM Johnson was aiming for a no-deal Brexit. (Newswires)

French Foreign Minister said that Brussels will not grant the UK an extension to A50 if the current circumstances remain the same. (Politico)

Plaid Cymru reportedly wish to use cross party discussions to consider the idea of impeaching UK PM Johnson in the event that he attempts to stop a Brexit extension. (Sky News)

Irish PM Varadkar said he does not expect any breakthroughs in Monday's meeting with UK PM Johnson but that the meeting is an opportunity to establish a common ground. (Virgin Media News)

BoE Financial Stability Executive Director Brazier said BoE has properly prepared lenders for shock of Brexit and that an imminent change of Governor will not derail the Bank. (Newswires)

 

ECB’s De Guindos said policy can play a greater countercyclical and stabilizing role, while he added that fiscal space should be used wisely in countries where it exists. (Newswires)

 

FX

 

DXY traded steady following the recent miss in US Non-Farm Payrolls and upbeat comments by Fed Chair Powell on the economy which suggested a lack of urgency for a more aggressive move by the Fed. EUR/USD was rangebound near Friday’s lows at the 1.1000 handle and GBP/USD traded tentative below 1.2300 as participants looked ahead to another attempt by the government to push through a general election in parliament today. Furthermore, UK PM Johnson was said to draw up a plan to legally sabotage a Brexit extension if MPs vote against holding a general election, although he was later reported to have signalled to cabinet ministers the government would have to accept a 3-month Brexit delay if it is forced on him by the courts, and his cabinet suffered another high-profile resignation in which Works and Pensions Secretary Rudd quit due to Brexit inaction and suggested that the PM was aiming for a no-deal Brexit. Elsewhere, USD/JPY remained unchanged and antipodeans conformed to the archetypal post-NFP lull as the effects of a firmer than expected CNY reference rate was offset by the weak Chinese trade data.

Turkish President Erdogan stated that Turkey will reduce interest rates to single digits and that inflation will follow suit. In other news, the Turkish Trade Minister asked US to lift barriers as well as increase trade, and the US is said to have set the goal of quadrupling trade to USD 100bln annually, while China and Turkey have signed MoU’s to boost trade. (Newswires/Xinhua)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed overnight in which WTI crude futures extended on Friday’s rebound to reclaim the USD 57.00/bbl level following the shake up in OPEC’s top ranks in which Saudi replace Energy Minister Al-Falih with Prince Abdulaziz, while some suggested the move was part of efforts to prepare for the Aramco IPO and followed a continued failure to boost oil prices to the kingdom’s preferred USD 80/bbl level. Elsewhere, gold was steady amid similar flat trade in the greenback and copper prices also traded lacklustre amid early weakness in Chinese commodity prices after weaker than expected Chinese trade data. 

Saudi Arabia removed Energy Minister Al-Falih from position and replaced him with Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman bin Abdulaziz al-Saud. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

 

US Secretary of State Pompeo said he thinks the Trump administration will announce vision for Middle East peace in coming weeks, while he also tweeted that Iran announced it will violate all limits and noted the fact that Iran retains massive uranium enrichment capacity reveals a core weakness of the deal. (Newswires/Twitter)

Iranian oil tanker Adrian Daria 1 reportedly unloaded its cargo of oil at a Syrian port, while there were separate reports that a US official warned that the US will continue to sanction whoever purchases Iranian oil or conducts business with its Revolutionary Guards. (Newswires/Al Jazeera)

 

US

At settlement, Treasuries have bull-flattened, with major curve spreads narrower by between 1-3bps. Overnight, the bias was to the downside, as geopolitical and trade related news flow became more constructive. The complex ticked higher in wake of a disappointing NFP headline, however, although there were some gyrations as traders' digested the data in wake of the release, which did show wage growth was solid. However, the T-Note came off highs after remarks from Fed chair Powell, who seemed upbeat on the economy, and signalled no concerns that could justify a 50bps rate cut at the 18th September FOMC. The market is still priced for 25bps. The Fed now enters blackout period, with attention on the central bank front moving towards Thursday's ECB, where a package of stimulus is expected to be unveiled, and will likely see T-Notes taking cues from Bunds. US T-note futures settled 2+ ticks higher at 131-12.

Fed Chair Powell said the Fed will act as appropriate to sustain the economic expansion when asked if the Fed will provide accommodation, while he added the Fed is watching all developments, geopolitical risks and financial conditions. Powell also commented that the labour market is in a good place and the labour market report is consistent with that story, while he reiterated the Fed will act appropriately to sustain the expansion. Powell added the economy is in the longest expansion since records began and the outlook is still favourable but noted risks to the outlook include slowing global growth and low inflation, while he cited trade tensions and Brexit as factors dampening global growth. (Newswires)
